entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud Public Security now integrates with leading SIEM solutions
entry.content:
Cloud Security Just Got Easier: S/4HANA Cloud Public Security now integrates with leading SIEM solutions

Introduction

We have some exciting news to share, which emphasizes the strategic importance of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and delivers upon our promise to strengthen cloud security: our security relevant APIs are now integrated with three major SIEM platforms – Microsoft Sentinel, Splunk, and Security Bridge.

This integration opens up new possibilities for customers to connect their SAP Cloud environments with their existing security operations, enabling faster threat detection, streamlined compliance, and better visibility across hybrid landscapes.

Three Use Cases, One API Strategy

The security APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are designed to support three major use cases:

  • SIEM (Security Information and Event Management): For real-time event monitoring and threat detection.
  • SSPM (SaaS Security Posture Management): To assess and maintain your system’s security configuration.
  • CASB (Cloud Access Security Broker): For monitoring user behavior and enforcing security policies.

Even within the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, these use cases will give you valuable insight into your security posture, enable a comprehensive security monitoring and will help you to enforce your security policies across your entire system landscape, including your cloud applications.

The Corner Stone: Security Audit Log (SAL) API

As mentioned, security in the cloud is a shared effort. SAP, as the cloud provider, handles infrastructure-level protection – think database security, OS patching, and physical data center controls. But what happens inside the application – user access, configuration, and monitoring – is the customer’s responsibility.

That’s where the SAL API comes in. It provides direct access to the Security Audit Log, capturing key events like successful and failed logins, transaction starts, or authorization checks. These logs are essential for understanding what’s happening in customers applications and to identify potential threats as soon as they occur.

Traditionally, SIEM tools have focused on infrastructure logs. Without application-level visibility, you’re missing half the picture. The SAL API bridges that gap. It’s a RESTful API delivering data in JSON format, ready for integration with modern security platforms. You can filter by event type, time range, and more – making it suitable for real-time monitoring, forensic analysis, and audit reporting.

The SAL API is your window into the application layer – and a key enabler for fulfilling your responsibilities under the shared security model.

More Than Just SAL: Event-Based vs. Configuration APIs

But there is more for a comprehensive picture of your security posture than just capturing SAL events. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offers a rich set of additional security-relevant APIs, and it’s important to understand how they map to the different use cases.

Event-Based APIs (for SIEM and CASB)

These APIs deliver real-time or historical event data and are ideal for SIEM systems that correlate and analyze logs for threat detection and incident response:

  • Security Audit Log API: Captures system-level events like logins, transaction starts, and authorization checks.
  • Read Access Log API: Records user access to sensitive data objects, helping detect unauthorized access.
  • Business User Change API: Tracks changes to user master data, such as name updates or role assignments.
  • Business Role Change API: Logs modifications to business roles, including who made the change and when.

These APIs are essential for building audit trails, supporting forensic investigations, and maintaining compliance.

Configuration & Static APIs (for SSPM)

SSPM tools focus on the current security posture of your system – how it’s configured and whether it aligns with best practices. These APIs provide read access to configuration data and help detect misconfigurations or unused entities:

  • Business User & Role Read APIs: Provides current state information about users and roles in the system.
  • Communication User, System & Arrangement APIs: Offers insights into how external systems and users are connected and authenticated.
  • HTTP Protection Configuration APIs: Helps monitoring and validating content security policies and allowlist configurations.
  • Trusted Certificates API: Lists certificates used for secure communication, helping ensure encryption and trust relationships are properly maintained.

Together, these APIs will provide you with all the information you need in order to support the three use cases mentioned above. But how do these APIs fit into a more general security strategy, beyond your business applications. That’s where our partners come in.

Partner Integrations: It’s Happening

We’re super excited that our partners have reacted quickly on the recently published APIs and have already integrated SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition into their security solutions.  Microsoft Sentinel, Splunk, and Security Bridge have built integrations, starting with the SAL API, so customers can get started quickly – no custom development required.

If you’re heading to SAP TechEd, you’ll hear more about these integrations and how they fit into SAP’s broader security strategy. It’s not just a feature drop – it’s part of a bigger story about making cloud security smarter and more connected.

Final Thoughts

The SAL API and its companion interfaces mark a turning point in how customers can manage security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. With native SIEM integrations, a clear shared responsibility model, and growing partner support, it’s never been easier to take control of your cloud security.

entry.title: SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Dallas focused on the intersection of AI and UX
entry.content:
Thanks to the ASUG Dallas chapter for helping us reach new audiences with SAP Fiori Innovation Day Dallas. We had a dedicated track within the larger ASUG event in which participants could learn about the latest user experience innovations, build an SAP Fiori elements app in less than 90 minutes, and see some sneak previews of AI-powered functionality that we’re working on. They also asked our sponsors questions during a panel discussion and found many useful tips they could use back in the office.

In the keynote, ASUG CEO, Geoff Scott, made a compelling case that moving to the cloud is a prerequisite for innovation at speed. In his interactive session, he polled the audience to give people a sense of how they compare to their peers in terms of innovation and adoption of various technologies. Many companies were using AI in some capacity, and some rely on multiple AI tools.  It was interesting to see what use cases the attendees find most relevant.

ASUG found that automation and analytics are the top AI use cases.

In the UX Strategy and What’s New section, Ioannis and Ute talked about the continuing evolution of SAP Fiori, how SAP Fiori elements brings the Fiori design system to apps in SAP S/4HANA, and demoed the Fiori experience in SAP Cloud ERP. They showed new AI-powered capabilities in My Home, such as Recap and recommendations, and explained how AI built into the SAP Fiori elements framework powers easy filter, smart summarization, and error explanation. All of this functionality combines to make business users more productive by making it faster and easier to find the apps and data they need in their S/4HANA system.

We had a day full of learning and fun.

In the partner panel, experts from Mygo Consulting, Qubittron, Mindset Consulting, and cbs Corporate Business Solutions shared their expertise on:

  • How organizations measure the return on investment for UX and AI projects.
  • Where AI playing a role in UX and how agents fit into the picture.
  • The relative value of AI for business users and developers.
  • The top AI use cases that make sense for companies
  • Where to focus your efforts in the near term to gain benefits from AI

Thanks to Sujeeth, Sidhartha, Andy, and Bastian for your unique insights and actionable advice. I found it interesting that many of the topics that people mentioned would be useful in the future were already part of our “one more thing” session at the end of the day.

The hands-on workshop focused on using AI to accelerate the process of building SAP Fiori apps. Participants used AI in three main ways:

  1. Gathering user requirements in a business requirement documents or via sketching
  2. Uploading the resulting document into SAP Fiori tools AI to generate an SAP Fiori elements app
  3. Making further updates and refinements to the application

We used SAP Fiori tools extensively. This is a logical choice since they are built into SAP Business Application Studio.

The final session of the day (and highest rated) was our lab preview / sneak peak at a few projects are currently in development. As with any discussion of future functionality, we made it clear that these demos might or might not turn into actual products. With this in mind, Sebastian and Katja showed:

  • Vibe coding using MCP servers. (Vibe coding was also part of the ASUG keynote, so this is clearly becoming a mainstream topic, at least among software developers.)
  • App Finder to make it easier to find information in your S/4HANA system.
  • Easy Fill, which speeds up data entry by extracting content from an email or other text and using it to update the relevant fields in an app built using an SAP Fiori elements object page.
  • Smart Helpers to make it easier to get your work done in SAP. I’m being deliberately vague here as we’ll share more at SAP TechEd and its companion roadshows in early November 2025.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

SAP Presenters (in order of appearance): Ioannis Grammatikakis, Ute Oemler, Sebastian Steinhauer, Katja Zoch

SAP Fiori Innovation Day sponsors: cbs Corporate Business Solutions, Mindset Consulting, Qubittron, and Mygo Consulting

ASUG events team: Nicole Kern, Kara Hughes

ASUG volunteers: Heather Davis, Simon To

Behind the scenes team: all the developers, architects, product managers and other colleagues who built the functionality and set up the demos and hands-on systems.

All the customers: we appreciate your questions, which help us understand your priorities and focus our development resources.

Next steps

  • Register for the monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable call to meet other developers and architects who build SAP Fiori apps.
  • Subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter, in which we share updates on SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, SAPUI5, and SAP Build Code every other month.
  • Explore the SAP Fiori Development Portal to see how SAP Fiori elements can boost developer productivity, drive UX consistency, and ensure your apps have the enterprise readiness features your users expect.
  • Join us at TechEd Berlin or virtual or at the next SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf

entry.title: UX Loves Innovation: Showcasing the crucial role of User Research
entry.content:
On October 15, we hosted our fourth “UX Loves Innovation” event in Walldorf. This time with a spotlight on current Business Suite UX User Research and Experiences of the Future projects plus one very special guest! 

Celebrating UX and innovation together 
Manoj Swaminathan, SAP Head of Business Suite, Finance, and Spend, and Alex Calvert, Head of SAP Business Suite UX Research & Engagements, kicked off the event with an inspiring half hour talk about the importance of User Research, how customers want to engage and evolve our products with us, and the role that AI and Agents play in our future experiences. Colleagues could spend the following two hours from 10am till lunch to visit the five booths dedicated to research topics in the Business Suite UX organization plus a chance to catch up with colleagues in their own time over coffee and some snacks. 

We were very impressed to see over 150 colleagues from many different areas of SAP with a great interest in user experience and user research stepping by and enjoying the friendly and productive atmosphere. 

Our booths: Five User Research projects for Business Suite UX 

  • Booth 1: GenUI – Welcome to an app-free world! 
    Showcased how dynamically created and personalized SAP user interface can look like. 
  • Booth 2:  Your AI-Powered Research Partner 
    Presented a prototype of an AI-powered assistant designed to scale user research learning and planning. 
  • Booth 3: A Day in a Life of a Billing Clerk 
    Demonstrated research objectives that aim to deeply understand user challenges with real-world billing workflows.
  • Booth 4: The Behavioural Analytics Edge 
    Presented how to decode user behaviour and design delightful experiences with behavioural analytics.
  • Booth 5: SAP Business Suite 
    Focused on the SAP Business Suite strategy, how we co-innovate with customers and how to get access to usage and experience data across the Suite. 

From insights to impact 

What we say about the role of user research in product development also applies to the event: It is so important to meet in one room, bring in an open mind, and have the time to exchange in a diverse group. 

We started these UX Loves Innovation – events in our coffee corner in Walldorf in 2024 as an opportunity for colleagues to meet each other in person, understand what other teams are currently working on and have an exchange across different areas. 

It is such a joy to see how this event developed to a recurring series with more and more colleagues contributing and joining each time. This is a great chance to bring great topics and great people together and we would encourage you to try out your own local version of "UX loves Innovations” yourselves wherever you are in the world. 

SAP has some amazing innovations and ideas that can improve the experience that our customers have today and giving us inspiration and information on how they experiences will evolve in the future. We want to make it simple for our colleagues to have a chance to learn and share in a positive and uplifting environment, and we hope they will also bring their topics for booths for future events as well!

entry.title: BigCommerce seamless integration with SAP Cloud ERP - Complete Setup & Demo Guide
entry.content:
Tired of Juggling Data Between SAP Cloud ERP and BigCommerce? We’ve Got You Covered!

Managing data and business processes across SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition) and BigCommerce can often be a challenging and time-consuming task — especially when done manually or through custom-built integrations. That’s why we’re excited to introduce a ready-to-use integration package powered by SAP Integration Suite, built to simplify and streamline your operations.

Designed specifically for B2C commerce scenarios, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce integration package ensures:

  • Seamless data synchronization between SAP and BigCommerce
  • Automated workflows for key business processes
  • A reduction in manual tasks and potential errors

In this blog, we’ll start with a high-level overview of what the integration offers. Then, we’ll walk you through a step-by-step guide to setting up the package — so you can get your systems connected and running efficiently with minimal effort.

Note : SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce integration package accelerator isn’t just limited to B2C. Partners can extend the integration to support B2B use cases as well, tailoring it to fit the needs of more complex business models. The package is built with extensibility in mind, so partners can enhance it further to accommodate specific business requirements or tailor it to specific industry needs. Partner can enhace the Integration Flows for bidirectional synchronization between BigCommerce & SAP Cloud ERP for the following entities:

  • Products, Price, Discounts & Tax
  • Product Variants ( Recommend customer project to leverage separate Products )
  • B2B Customer Master Data & Payment Settlement Flows
  • Enhance the use-case to cover Promotions and Classification

 

Overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce Integration Package:

SAP provides a variety of pre-built integration accelerators via the SAP Integration Suite, all accessible through the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Among these, we’ve developed a dedicated BigCommerce integration accelerator that enables a seamless connection between your BigCommerce storefront and SAP Cloud ERP and its available with SAP Cloud Integration Suite Starter Edition and Standard Edition.

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce integration package ensures real-time data consistency across both platforms by synchronizing key business objects such as:

  •  🛒  Product information
  •  📦  Inventory levels/Product Stock
  • 💲Product Prices & Discounts 
  •  👤  Customer information

By automating critical business processes like order creation, cancellations, and returns, the integration reduces manual effort, minimizes errors, and increases operational efficiency. It also synchronizes shipping and delivery details, helping you provide accurate and timely updates to customers — a key to delivering a superior B2C customer experience.

The BigCommerce Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud package is designed to integrate key end-to-end business processes between SAP Cloud ERP and BigCommerce, enabling smooth, automated data flow and operational consistency across both platforms.

The following core business processes are supported out of the box:

📦 From SAP Cloud ERP to BigCommerce:

  • ✅ Replicate Products – Ensure accurate and up-to-date product information is reflected in your BigCommerce storefront.
  • 📊 Replicate Product Stock – Keep inventory levels in sync to avoid overselling or stockouts.
  • 💲 Replicate Product Prices & Discounts – Automatically update pricing and promotional details in BigCommerce.
  • 🚚 Replicate Delivery Details – Provide timely and accurate shipping information to your customers via BigCommerce.

🛒From BigCommerce to SAP Cloud ERP:

  • 👥 Replicate B2C Customers – Capture and transfer customer data from BigCommerce to SAP, enabling centralized customer management.
  • 🧾Replicate Orders – Seamlessly transfer incoming sales orders into SAP for fulfillment and processing.
  • ❌ Replicate Order Cancellations – Reflect cancelled orders in SAP for proper stock and financial reconciliation.
  • 🔁 Replicate Order Returns – Automatically push return details from BigCommerce into SAP to streamline reverse logistics.

Together, these integration flows deliver a robust, automated B2C commerce experience, reducing manual interventions and ensuring your front-end and back-end systems remain in sync.

🚀 How to Set Up the “BigCommerce Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Public Edition” Package

Integrating BigCommerce with SAP Cloud ERP is now easier than ever — thanks to the pre-built accelerator available on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This step-by-step guide will help you configure and deploy the integration package using SAP Integration Suite, so your systems can work together seamlessly.

✅Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

  • 🔑  An SAP Partner Account with access to SAP Integration Suite (via SAP BTP – Business Technology Platform).
  • 🧾 Access to SAP Cloud ERP.
  • 🛍  A BigCommerce Partner or Merchant Account.SAP Cloud ERP
  • 📘  Basic knowledge of SAP BTP, Integration Suite and BigCommerce . 
  • 🌐  Access to SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  • 📘Detailed Configure Guide - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  • Refer to BigCommerce Receiver Adapter | SAP Help Portal

 🛠️  Step 1: Set Up SAP Integration Suite instance using SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) account.

  1. Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  2. Create a Subaccount and enable Integration Suite:
    • Navigate to your Global Account > Subaccount.
    • Create or open an Integration Suite instance.
    • Assign relevant entitlements and Assign relevant roles
    • Use the Booster Enable Integration Suite to automate setup or configure manually
    • for more details refer to sap help documentation SAP Integration Suite | SAP Help Portal

📦 Step 2: Import the BigCommerce Adapter Package into SAP Integration Suite

  1. Goto SAP Integration Suite instance
  2. Go to Discover tab.
  3. Search for “BigCommerce Adapter for SAP Integration Suite”.
  • Click “Copy” to add / move the package to your Design workspace.

  • To Configure BigCommerce Adapter Installation - Installing the BigCommerce Adapter is a prerequisite to use the Integration Content. For adapter installation, refer to the “BigCommerce Adapter Guide” and also refer to section Configure Adapter in Communication Channels and documents section in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

🔄Step 3: Configure BigCommerce iFlows (Integration Flows) with API access relevant details.

  1. Go to Design > Integrations in the Integration Suite.
  2. Open the imported BigCommerce Integration Package.
  3. Select a relevant iFlow (e.g., Replicate Orders from BigCommerce to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  4. Configure the necessary Externalized Parameters and Connections, referencing the detailed documentation for each Integration Flow.
  5. To Configuration in SAP Cloud ERP - the mandatory configurations which need to be performed in the SAP Cloud ERP before you can start implementing the configuration for BigCommerce API and configuring the Integration Content in SAP Integration Suite and for more details refer to section "Configuration in SAP Cloud ERP" in configuration guide SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce Configuration Guide in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  6. Sample configuration shown below.

      BigCommerce Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • BigCommerce Base Url: https://<yourshop>.myBigCommerce.com/
  • BigCommerce Secure Parameter: The name of the BigCommerce access token secure parameter 

       SAP Cloud ERP Receiver Adapter Connection Configuration

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Base Url: https://<your-sap-s4-hana-instance-id>-api.s4hana.cloud.sap
  • Credential Name: The name of the SAP Cloud ERP secure parameter 

🧩 Example Integration Flows:

  • BigCommerce ➜ SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition : Customer Replication, New Orders, Order Cancellations & Returns
  • SAP S4HANA Public Cloud Edition ➜ BigCommerce : Products, Inventory Synchronization, Stock Availability, Delivery Status

🚀Step 4: Deploy and Test the Integration Package in Integration Suite

  1. Deploy selected iFlows from your Design workspace.
  2. Monitor from Monitor > Integrations > Message Processing Logs.
  3. Perform test transactions: for more details refer to Demo section in the blog
    • Place a test order in BigCommerce.
    • Monitor the message logs and confirm data replication in SAP Cloud ERP: Sales Orders, Business Partners, Product Catalog

🔧 Extend or Customize the Package (Optional)

As a partner you can extend or tailor the integration through:

  • Customer Exits to plug-in your custom integration flows (Pre Exits and Post Exits in Intergration Flows)
  • Copy and modify the integration content.
  • Groovy scripts to customize payload mappings.
  • Content Modifiers to apply business logic.
  • Enhanced error handling and alerting.

 💡 Partner Tips & Monetization Opportunities

As an SAP Partner, you can:

  • 💡 Extend the integration flows and Build new integration flows using SAP BigCommerce adapter
  • 📜  Demo your solution with real-time order sync and inventory updates, build a demo to show real-time sync between BigCommerce and SAP with custom business case.
  • 🧰 Buildc Multi-Tenant Integration Templates for reuse across customers.
  • 🧠 Leverage SAP Integration Advisor for intelligent mapping.
  • 💡  Add your branding, services, or vertical-specific enhancements.

High Level Demo Flow to showcase Order processing along with Master data replication.

  • Step 1 : View the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce integration package in Integration Suite
  • Step 2: Show product in SAP Cloud ERP  (to be replicated to BigCommerce)
  • Step 3: Start replication of product in integration suite
  • Step 4: Show replicated product in BigCommerce and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product
  • Step 5: Log into BigCommerce as customer and browse through existing products
  • Step 6: Select the product replicated from SAP Cloud ERP and add to basket
  • Step 7: Enter the relevant details like payment and create order
  • Step 8: Check the order created in BigCommerce
  • Step 9: Replicate the order from BigCommerce to SAP Cloud ERP
  • Step 10: Log into SAP Cloud ERP as internal_sales_rep and look for “Manage Sales Order Version 2” app and open the sales order and change the order date to todays date (both in header and item level) and Save sales order
  • Step 11: Log into SAP Cloud ERP as shipping_specialist and open app “Create outbound delivery with order reference”
  • Step 12: Enter shipping point and enter the sales order and shipping date as todays date and save , note down the Outbound Delivery ID
  • Step 13: Open app “pick outbound delivery” and enter Outbound Delivery ID and enter Actual GI Date DD/MM/YYYY (valid date, example 07/01/2025) , enter picking quantity as 1 and save
  • Step 14 : Click on Post GI and status of Outbound Delivery picking changes to Completely Processed. Note : show the SO Process flow of created order in SAP Cloud ERP
  • Step 15 : Replicate the Outbound delivery from SAP Cloud ERP to BigCommerce.
  • Step 16: Open sales order in BigCommerce and show the OD created in SAP Cloud ERP reflected in metadata fields of Sales order and status of Sales Order is changed to fulfilled.

Detailed Demo steps:

BigCommerce Demo systems include the following systems - Integration Suite Tenant [along with BTP Sub-Account), SAP Cloud ERP, BigCommerce Admin Portal

Step 1:  Access the  Integration Suite tenant and view “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce” integration package

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to “Discover” -> “Integration”
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce”  , view the integration flows and details. 

Step 2: Access to SAP Cloud ERP System to show the replicating product master

  • Access system using URL SAP Cloud ERP system as Product Master Specialist
  • Login with user = prodmaster_specialist
  • Launch the App : “Manage Product Master Data”  and search for Product ID  (sample product ID - TG11)
  • Note: in the demo product replication integration flow we are replicating only one product with product ID (sample product ID - TG11) and user could decide to replicate all products / sub-set of products, based on specific functional requirements.

Step 3: Start replication of product in Integration Suite

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Discover -> Integration (only first time)
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce”  , open the integration package -> copy the package
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce”  ,
  • Navigate to “artifacts” and search for integration package “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to BigCommerce”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to BigCommerce”
    • To deploy => click on the “3 dots” of integration package and select “deploy”
    • Deploy would start the product replication from SAP Cloud ERP to BigCommerce

Step 4: Show replicated product in BigCommerce and add picture and select the sales channel to be online store and activate the product

  • Login using URL : BigCommerce
  • Navigate to “Products”
  • Check and prepare the product for selling to customer
    • Check the product is replicated
    • Check the Stock, Price (Default Price) , SKU (Product ID in S4 Public)
    • Check the product Inventory Details (Current Stock)  
    • Add the picture to publish 
    • Make sure to change the visibility status of product from "Disabled" to "Visible"
    • Note: only the product visibility status is "Visible" can be sold .
  • “Save” the product

Step 5: login to BigCommerce as customer and browse through existing products

Step 6: select the product replicated from SAP Cloud ERP and add to basket

  • Navigate to "Orders" -> "All Orders" 
  • Click on "Add" 
  • In the first step of order creation, enter the "Customer Info" , enter the "Existing Customer" / "Create New Customer" 
  • Search for the "Existing Customer" and Select the Currency
  • Enter the Billing Information 
  • Add the Product , Search for the existing replicated Product
  • Click on Next
  • Select the Fulfillment, 

Step 7: enter the relevant details like payment details

  • Select the Payment Provider, Card Type, Expiration Date details
  • Enter the Credit Card Holder Name, Credit Card Number, 
  • Click on "Save and Process Payment"  , order would be placed         

Step 8: check the order created in BigCommerce

  • Navigate to “Orders” -> "All Orders" 
  • Check the order created with status “Awaiting Fulfillment” , note down the “SAP Cloud ERP Order ID”  , order ID would be used to search order created in SAP Cloud ERP system      
  • Note: SAP Cloud ERP Order ID can be found "Metafields" 

Step 9: replicate the order from BigCommerce to SAP Cloud ERP

  • Open Integration Suite
  • Navigate to Design -> Integration and API’s
  • Search for integration Package “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Integration with BigCommerce”  , open the integration package -> navigate to Artifacts , search for artifact “Replicate Orders from BigCommerce to SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition”
  • Deploy the integration flow “Replicate Products from SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition to BigCommerce”
  • Replication of orders in status Unfulfilled would be moved to SAP Cloud ERP .

entry.title: [Session Reply & Slides Available] Hot Topic: Joule Activation for SAP Cloud ERP (Public Edition)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Expertise Service Team and SAP AI RIG team recently co-present a deep-dive session focused on enabling ‌Joule‌ - SAP’s generative AI copilot - for SAP Cloud ERP.

The agenda covered as below and feel free to access [Slides] [Recording]. 

  • Business AI capabilities and use cases
  • Joule’s technical architecture on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)
  • Step-by-step activation process for S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Q&A and live troubleshooting

1. Key Objectives‌

  • Demonstrate Joule’s value in streamlining business processes (e.g., sales order management, issue resolution in status check).
  • Guide participants through end-to-end setup using BTP booster, destinations, and identity management.
  • Equip partners to deploy Joule for customers with minimal friction.

2. Business AI & Joule Introduction‌

Joule Definition‌
  • SAP’s generative AI copilot embedded in cloud solutions to automate tasks, provide contextual insights, and reduce manual effort.
Primary Use Case‌:
  • Navigational support (e.g., finding apps without memorizing transaction codes)
  • Transactional support (e.g., creating insights cards, resolving incomplete sales orders)
  • Informational support (e.g., find SAP Help document for relevant business process)
Demo Highlight
  • Create Insights Cards with Joule
  • Check Sales Order Status with Joule‌:Joule identifies incomplete orders, highlights missing fields (e.g., payment terms), and guides users to resolve issues

3. Technical Architecture & Activation Flow‌

3.1 Core Components‌:

  • Joule Web Client‌ is embedded across SAP cloud solutions (e.g., SuccessFactors, S/4HANA)
  • BTP Subaccount‌
    • Hosts Joule instance
    • SAP Build Work Zone
    • connectivity services
  • Cloud Identity Services‌
    • Manages authentication (IAS)
    • Identity / role synchronization (IPS)
  • S/4HANA Cloud APIs‌: Data source for Joule’s responses.

3.2 Activation Steps‌:

Prerequisites‌:
  • BTP global account with Joule entitlements
  • S/4HANA system registered to BTP
BTP Subaccount Setup‌:
  • Create subaccount in preferred region/hyperscaler
  • Assign entitlements:
    • SAP Build Work Zone (foundation or standard edition)
    • Joule service
  • Establish trust to Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Add S/4HANA domain to trusted destinations
Joule Booster Execution‌:
  • Guided setup for BTP formations.
  • Integrate S/4HANA, Build Work Zone, and Cloud Identity Services
Post-Booster Configurations‌:
  • Verify communication arrangements in S/4HANA (e.g., Digital Assistant Service - 0882).
  • Verify BTP Destinations
  • Verify SAP Build Work Zone Content for S/4HANA
  • Configure Identity Provisioning (IPS) to sync users/roles from S/4HANA to Build Work Zone
Validation‌:
  • Ensure Joule icon appears in S/4HANA Launchpad.
  • Test capabilities (e.g., querying open sales orders).

4. Critical Notes & Pitfalls‌

  • Trust Configuration‌: Ensure all solutions in a Joule formation use the ‌same Cloud Identity Services tenant‌.
  • Destination Errors‌: Verify hostnames, client IDs, and secrets in navigation service manually if not auto-generated.
  • Identity Provisioning‌: Ensure IPS jobs run successfully to propagate roles to SAP Build Work Zone.

5. Next Steps & Resources‌

  1. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4538/4826/
  2. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4452/4738/

  • SAP Community - Business AI 
  • SAP Support for technical errors.

  • Vietnam localization for implementation (Oct 28th)

entry.title: Exploring Business Partner Master Data with SAP Joule, the AI Co-pilot
entry.content:
In today’s ever-evolving business landscape, quick access to business partners and their specific details is crucial for success. But this can be tedious and time-consuming when you have a lot of master data objects, especially when you want to quickly fetch some specific information related to a section of the master data without having to open the FIORI app and click through multiple facets in the user interface to locate the required information.

With the latest update of SAPJoule in October 2025, Business Partner master data brings you the power of AI. With Joule's robust functionality, you can easily access and view detailed information about your Business Partners, enhancing your ability to make informed decisions and streamline operations. This blog post explores how Joule can become your go-to assistant for easily accessing Business Partners efficiently.

 

A Closer Look at Business Partners

Joule offers features that allow users to delve into various aspects of Business Partner data. With Joule, you can explore:

  • Overview: Quickly access a summary of key information about your Business Partners.
  • Basic Details: Review fundamental data points, including organisation title and identifying search terms.
  • Roles: Understand the roles your Business Partners fulfil and their associated descriptions.
  • Addresses: Examine details of maintained and standard addresses across regions.
  • Industries: Gain insights into the industry classifications of your Business Partners.
  • Relationships: Explore the interconnected web of relationships between your Business Partners.

 

Joule’s Requirements

Before diving into Joule's capabilities, ensure you meet the prerequisites for access. You must be assigned the business role: SAP_BR_BUPA_MASTER_SPECIALIST to leverage Joule.

 

Practical Use Cases for Business Partners

Display Business Partner Overview

Kickstart your exploration by asking Joule to show you an overview of a Business Partner. For instance, entering the Joule prompt, "Display Business Partner Overview" followed by specifying an ID such as “10238179”, will yield an informative card with essential details like Full Name, Business Partner ID, Category, and Communication Details.

 

Joule knows what else you might need

You read that right! Joule right away brings up the relevant supported details of the business partner in the form of quick links.

 

All that you must do is click any of the navigational links to view the corresponding details of the business partner. Everything in the same conversation window with Joule!

Joule also provides you with the navigation to the app where the business partner is stored. With just a click, you can open the object to view all its details or edit it to make changes.

Now let’s speed up things. What if you don’t want to go step by step. You know the business partner's number, and you quickly want to view some specific information. Well, Joule does that too!

 

Dive into Basic Details

To uncover foundational insights, ask Joule, "Show me basic data of business partner 10238179." This query retrieves critical information, including Authorization Group and Archiving Flags.

Unveiling Roles

Discover the various roles a Business Partner plays in your organisation by requesting Joule to "Display roles of business partner 10238179." Learn about the roles, their descriptions, and their validity periods.

 

Navigating Addresses

Addresses are pivotal in maintaining smooth communication. By querying "Display addresses of business partner 10238179," you can access all address entries and their specifics, ensuring that communication remains seamless.

Industry Insights

To understand the industry dynamics, ask Joule to “For BP 10238179, show me industry details”. This reveals the Business Partner’s industry designations and systems.

Exploring Relationships

The intricate network of relationships is crucial for operational success. Joule can help display all related business partners by querying "Display relationship of BP 10238179," providing insights into all maintained relationships. Furthermore, for each related business partner, Joule reveals the Relationship Category, validity, and associated fields based on the relationship category.

 

Practical Use Cases for Customer Master Data

Display Customer Overview

Initiate your exploration of customer master data by querying an overview. Simply start with "Show me customers overview," and specify a Customer ID such as “1007885” for detailed insights. Joule retrieves essential information like full name, Customer ID, and contact details.

 

It works the same way as that of Business Partner. Quick links help you fetch more relevant details about the Customer master data.

 

Navigate Customer Information

Dive further with specific queries like, "Show me customer information for 1023060," to uncover details such as account group, authorization group, order block, and classification indicators.

Exploring Sales Area Dynamics

To view a customer’s sales area specifics, ask Joule, "Display sales area of customer 1023060." For further exploration into individual sales areas, a query such as "Display sales area details of customer 1023060 with sales area 1010 10 00" reveals insights like sales office locations, shipping condition, and payment terms.

Tax Data Delve

Tax considerations are crucial. By querying, "Display tax data of customer 1023060 with sales area 1010 10 00," you can access location-specific tax classifications and descriptions.

 

Financial Engagement: Company Code and Dunning

Explore financial coordination by asking Joule for company code details, with queries like "Display company code of customer 1023060." At the same time, examining dunning data can optimize collections – “Display dunning data of customer 1023060 with company code 4040" provides detailed procedural insights.

 

Conclusion

With this update, you can leverage Joule to access Business Partner and Customer objects. You can soon expect Joule for Supplier objects too.

Empower your business with Joule's capabilities and streamline your operations by effectively accessing Business Partner information. Whether it’s for ensuring precise communication or gaining industry insights, Joule stands ready to assist.

Embark on your journey with Joule today and redefine how you effectively access business partner and customer master data for success.

entry.title: Drive more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – A Recommendation Guide
entry.content:
After spending almost 10 years helping customers activate and operate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, I wanted to provide a quick guide on some initiatives based on my experience that you can follow to get more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This blog will cover some of the top recommendations but is by no means a conclusive or complete list, as there are many other topics that can be added. Now, some of these recommendations may already be included in your subscription or some might not; this will be an individual customer situation, so I encourage you to contact your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner to inquire about your individual situation.

First, if you are reading this blog, it is because you have probably been operating SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some time and are looking to get more out of your subscription investment.

If you are reading this blog and you are planning to implement public cloud, I suggest you read this first.

Let me provide you with some of my highlights:

 

  • New Innovations – Find and explore new innovations using the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (SAP RASD - A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login) to analyze new innovations included in your subscription.  I have recommended this tool in previous blogs to get ready for upgrades so you can consume new innovation and maintain your system. However, in this case I want to focus on the topic of innovation only. The tool will highlight all innovations included in a release, or you can see the innovations tailored to your productive system usage. However you want to do this, I advise you to benefit from all this new innovation that was added to your system.

New Innovations - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

  • SAP Business Artificial Intelligence – The SAP RASD Tool can also support exploring the special use cases for SAP Business AI (SAP Joule, Agents, embedded AI). You can use the tool to showcase what has been added into the release. Similar to the above use case, the SAP RASD tool can showcase all the topics per release or tailor them to your productive usage for SAP Business AI.

SAP Business AI - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Another tool that can help you visualize the overall use cases for SAP Business AI is the SAP Discovery Center (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/index.html), which you can use to explore what is delivered as standard so you can use it to assess your business needs. The difference with the SAP RASD Tool is that SAP Discovery Center presents all available cases independent of release for all SAP product portfolios and can also be tailored by SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, etc.), while in the case of SAP RASD, it shows the information by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and by release (e.g., 2508).

SAP Business AI - SAP Discovery Center

I have written on the topic of foundational elements for Business AI before, so I advise you to review this blog that contains many more recommendations on this important subject: Foundational Elements for Harnessing the Power of Business AI in Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Ed.

 

  • Manage News Application – The Manage News Fiori application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers system administrators to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users through a centralized news feed. By tailoring communication to organizational needs, the application enhances visibility and keeps users informed of key system and company developments—all in a single, easily accessible location.

Manage News Application

News - My Home

 

  • Keep informed of the latest regulatory changes: If you have multi-country operations and footprint, I recommend using the SAP Regulatory Change Manager to always stay up to date with changes in regulations. More information can be found here.

SAP Regulatory Change Manager

 

  • 3 System Landscape – If you are running a two-system landscape, you might want to work with SAP so they can convert you to the latest and greatest 3 System Landscape. The 3 System Landscape comes with additional benefits that will help you drive much more business value out of your SAP investment. To learn more about this topic, I recommend this blog and video that explain the process and benefits.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - 3 System Landscape

 

  • Parallel Line: If you are on a 3-System landscape and are not using the parallel line, you are missing out. The parallel line will provide you with an additional environment you can use to run testing, training, mock-up loads, test new configuration, try the configuration localization toolkit, etc. The parallel line can be used to avoid impacts to the main line and current business operations.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Parallel Line

I have also written about this topic in detail in the past, so feel free to look at this blog with all details:  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, three-system landscape, parallel line – High Level Introduction.

 

  • 2-Tier ERP Strategy – Maybe you implemented SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some subsidiaries or maybe for your corporate business; however, the goal was, we are seeing more and more SAP customers running hybrid deployments to connect their SAP systems with either corporate headquarters running in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or looking at SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to bring new acquisitions or subsidiaries.

2-Tier ERP

The strategies are diverse and depend on your business requirements; however, SAP has many options to support you in this using our 2-tier models. I suggest you read this blog to learn more about these specific strategies: Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA.

 

  • Extending to the new SAP Business Suite Packages - In February 2025, SAP announced the new SAP Business Suite. The Business Suite serves as a transformation engine, helping customers generate rapid cycles of innovation and continuous improvement as a service. This enables organizations to deliver greater business value and achieve improved outcomes through end-to-end processes. So with the new SAP Business Suite, you have a great opportunity to complement your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with some of the current packages (e.g., SAP Strategic Procurement, SAP Core HR (which includes SuccessFactors for example), SAP CX, etc.), or potentially change your entire subscription to the new SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages to benefit from more entitlements that cover more functionality to address specific business pain points. This last point is not available yet, but is planned for 2026, so stay tuned. But a new installation and subscription can start with new SAP Business Suite Packages right away.

SAP Business Suite

This strategy could prepare you for future consumption models where you have much more capabilities at your disposal. I invite you to learn more about this topic here: Unpacking the new SAP Business Suite.

 

  • WalkMe – WalkMe can help you with the onboarding of new users (e.g., if you are bringing a new company code or new country rollout) as it helps drive user adoption using its capabilities to ease the use of the system by providing guided tours, samples, and even automations of tasks. At the moment, WalkMe provides out-of-the-box content for MyHome, Procurement Specialist, Sales Representative, and Financial Accountant, and more content will be added in the future. You can also use its current editor capabilities to create your own content and help drive user adoption and onboarding.

WalkMe & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • SAP Signavio Process Intelligence is a good option to really understand how the system is being used and try to drive enhancements based on current system usage and KPIs. Currently, SAP Signavio Process Intelligence offers two out-of-the-box processes including Order to Cash and Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) that can be used to drive inferences on these end-to-end processes. More end-to-end processes will be added in the future. However, customers can use Process Intelligence to create their own content to analyze their specific usage and drive enhancements to the overall system productivity and usage based on very concrete production data to help drive transformation of processes.

SAP Signavio Process Intelligence & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If you want to know more about SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, check this blog and example.

 

I hope this selective list of recommendations provides you some ideas for your new projects, new business rollouts, or new business requirements. Feel free to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer - Example in System
entry.content:
In previous blog (Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer -... - SAP Community), we made a brief introduction to Next Generation JIT S2C solution. In this blog, I would like to show how system run by testing in SAP internal S/4HANA Cloud Public edition system.

We still take the sequenced JIT call business in automobile industry as an example. After we confirm all the related master data are prepared, we test in system by reference the main process described in previous overview blog:

  1. Create the customer JIT Call manually by Fiori App Manage Customer JIT Calls

You specify the External JIT Call Number (This can be from customer), Customer Vehicle Number, Customer Vehicle Model and other customer information. These cover all the request information from customer.

Component Groups will be automatically determined after you added new components.

In App Monitor Customer JIT Calls, you may check all the created JIT Calls with the status showed.

  1. Following most actions related to JIT Calls can all be executed in App Manage Customer JIT Calls By Component Groups.

Select your Teams Name, appropriate functions that could be performed by this team are displayed. Click the action button to perform corresponding actions.

The first action is Create Packing Group:

After the action being successfully executed, you may check the application log by clicking the Application Log on the same screen.

The application log detail will tell you what happened to this JIT call by this action.

Now the Packing Group is created based on the package specification defined, and you will find the new created packing group in the component group information of JIT Call:

The Internal Processing Status was changed from JIT Call Created(0100) to Packing Group Allocated (0130):

Since we will supply the customer JIT request with production. Now we release the JIT call to production:

Updated status also displayed on the same screen:

Packing Group Status updated too:

After the production completed, we perform the confirmation by clicking Confirm Production:

Goods movement posted while performing the production confirmation with movement type 261 for component consumption and movement type 131 for product receiving.

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received → Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted → Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

hese rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 – Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 – Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP’s standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era — Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview — Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Key Design Principles

Principle Description
Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.
AI-enabledEmbedded Joule AI assistant supports planning and exception handling.
Network-readyPre-integrated with SAP Business Network for Logistics.
Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope — From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics — Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics — all running in the cloud.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit

InboundGoods receipt, putaway, inspectionReduce manual errors and waiting time.
InternalBin management, replenishmentOptimize space and movement.
OutboundPicking, packing, staging, loadingFaster fulfillment accuracy.
MobileScanning & task confirmationReal-time execution; paperless workflow.
MonitoringDashboards & alertsImprove supervisory visibility.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer’s regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels — no need for spreadsheets.

Key Fiori Apps in Warehouse Logistics

App Name Usage
Warehouse MonitorSupervisors track workload, resources, exceptions.
Execute Warehouse TasksOperators perform putaway/picking with handhelds.
Manage Inbound DeliveriesCreate, monitor, and post receipts for inbound deliveries.

Transportation Logistics — Intelligent Freight Orchestration

Transportation Logistics in LGM brings planning, tendering, execution, and freight costing into one intelligent workflow. It eliminates spreadsheet-based planning and manual RFQs by integrating real-time carrier collaboration.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
PlanningLoad building, route optimisation & consolidationCut freight costs and carbon footprint.
TenderingPeer-to-peer / broadcast to carriersAutomate carrier selection.
ExecutionFreight order tracking & event managementAchieve end-to-end visibility.
CostingFreight cost calculation & invoice reconciliationImprove financial accuracy.
AppointmentDock scheduling & time windowsReduce waiting time and idle assets.

Manage Freight RFQs App: A chemical manufacturer planning an urgent dispatch to Delhi creates an RFQ in LGM. Three carriers receive tenders instantly via BN4L; within minutes, Carrier A accepts with best price and lead time — no emails or phone calls needed.

Key Fiori Apps in Transportation Logistics

App Name Usage
Manage Freight RFQsCreate/manage carrier RFQs.
Tender Freight OrdersPublish freight offers to carriers.
Track Freight OrdersView live shipment events & status.

Network Collaboration — Connected by Design

Network Collaboration within SAP LGM links shippers and carriers digitally via the SAP Business Network for Logistics. It replaces emails and calls with structured collaboration — carrier tenders, dock appointments, shipment events, and POD uploads all happen in one network workspace.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
Carrier CollaborationTender acceptance / status updatesFaster onboarding, less manual follow-up.
Appointment SchedulingDock slot managementSmoother inbound/outbound flow.
Tracking & EventsMilestones & delay alertsPredictive visibility.
DocumentationProof of Delivery / Freight invoice sharingPaperless compliance.

Manage Carrier Collaboration App: A transport partner accepts a freight order from the shipper and uploads the signed POD once delivery is complete. The system automatically updates LGM and triggers freight invoice posting in ERP.

Key Fiori Apps in Network Collaboration

App Name Usage

Monitor Shipment MilestonesTrack shipment events and POD status.

Unified Planning & Control — Visibility in One View

Narrative
The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

Feature Description
Unified Planning ConsoleAggregate view of all logistics plans & statuses.
Control TowerMonitors execution progress and exceptions.
KPI DashboardsVisualises service levels and throughput.
Exception HandlingGuided workflows to resolve delays and errors.

Logistics Dashboard App: A distribution manager opens the dashboard each morning to view all facilities on one screen. If a lane’s OTD drops below 95 %, he drills into that carrier and sends an RFQ for replacement service — action taken within minutes, not days.

Key Fiori Apps in Unified Planning & Control

App Name Usage
Logistics DashboardKPI overview of logistics network.

Integration — Seamless by Default

LGM connects to SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network using standard APIs and content packages. Data flows bi-directionally for deliveries, goods movements, freight costs and invoices. This ensures a single source of truth across finance and operations.

Intelligence Layer — Joule AI for Smarter Decisions

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is built into LGM. It understands context, answers in natural language, and automates common decisions like carrier selection or route replanning.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

A planner types, “Which deliveries are at risk today?” Joule returns a list of orders facing delays and suggests rescheduling or alternate carriers based on historic performance. The planner approves in one click — no manual analysis

entry.title: Where to begin with SAP Requirements in Jira?
entry.content:
I think all of SAP project experts will agree that SAP Requirements Management is much more than an Excel file downloaded from the SAP Activate Roadmap accelerators list and filled with unstructured notes from Fit-2-Standard workshops. In practice, Requirements Management should be the bridge between business intent and tested, working functionality. And yet, this bridge often does not exist. The disconnect between what business processes should do and what finally goes live remains one of the biggest causes of rework and missed value in SAP programs.

Why managing requirements is important?

A weak requirements discipline leads later to solution scope creep, fragmented testing, and the famous “this isn’t what we expected” moment during the UAT. Well organized requirements management turns conversations into commitments - every requirement becomes traceable from the "Need" through "Realize and Test" to "Deploy". Traceability is the essence of governance in SAP Activate.

High-level business outcomes are defined during Discover and Prepare phase, while detailed functional, non-functional, and delta requirements are refined and documented during the Explore phase. They are documented against SAP Best Practice processes (for example BD9 - Sell from Stock).

Every requirement should be linked to its related Test Case and Work Package to ensure full traceability from Fit-to-Standard through Deployment. This linkage keeps it transparent, testable, and aligned with business value.

How SAP Activate Defines a Requirement

In the Requirements-to-Deploy (R2D) framework, a requirement is a single, testable statement describing the system behavior or capability needed to fulfill a business need.
Each requirement should be:
1) Atomic – one clear need, not a bundle of ideas.
2) Unambiguous – can be interpreted only in one way.
3) Traceable – linked to a Process, Scope Item and Work Package (deliverable).
4) Testable – verifiable through objective criteria.

A requirement is not a meeting note like ‘Need better reports’; it states precisely what the system must do. It defines what the system must achieve but not yet how to implement it.

When written in a standardized way, requirements become the shared language between Business and IT - the foundation for alignment, testing, and auditability.

 Practically in Jira

Ok, so if it is now clear what a requirement is and how it should be defined, the next question becomes where to manage all this effectively. That’s where Jira - when properly configured - becomes a practical backbone for collecting, tracking, and approving SAP requirements.

In Jira, requirements can be managed as custom Work Item types aligned with SAP Activate governance standards.

  1. Create a dedicated work item type called Requirement with a distinct icon.

  2. Configure essential fields and workflow statuses (e.g., Draft → To Be Approved → Approved → In Realization → Completed).

  3. Link each requirement to its Scope item, ensuring full traceability.

Once configured, you can collect requirements directly in Jira during your Fit-To-Standard workshops.

SAP native tools

While SAP Cloud ALM and Solution Manager’s Focused Build provide strong governance for requirement-to-deploy processes, many organizations still complement them with Jira to enable broader Agile methods delivery, integrate non-SAP workstreams, and leverage its native links with Confluence and Test automation tools. Also, there are a few integration tools available that allow for data exchange between Jira and SAP.

Your Goal

In any SAP project, your goal is to ensure that every piece of delivered and tested functionality traces back to at least one well-written requirement. However, the discipline lies not in the tool itself but in the governance structure and consistency with which it’s used.

entry.title: How to turn SAP workshop notes into clear and testable Requirements
entry.content:
During SAP Activate’s Explore phase and the Fit-to-Standard workshops, consultants capture dozens of “requirements,” each meant to articulate a specific business need. Without clear formulation standards, a few weeks later no one is quite sure what the original request actually meant. This undermines the workshop’s primary goal: validating solution fit.

The real pain - inconsistency

In SAP programs, requirements that are vague or inconsistently written become a main source of unnecessarily lost effort. When two workstreams describe the same business need in different words, duplication multiply which may lead to unnecessary testing of the same functionality or cause change requests.

For example, when a requirement says “system should support automatic approval” no one will know what support actually meant when they discussed it during a workshop. You cannot test such a requirement later.

Ambiguity has measurable cost

Each unclear requirement multiplies into unnecessary discussions, rework, and test defects. Misunderstandings accumulate silently until they become visible during the first cycle of testing, when the system finally reveals whether the requirement was truly met.

The true risk of Requirements Management is not the absence of requirements documentation, but the lack of consistency in how requirements are formulated.

Not having the requirement formulation standards, which are recommended by SAP Activate, is one of the major sources of rework and wasted effort. When requirements are written in different formats and tones, they cannot be easily classified, compared, or reused.

Why clear formulation matters

SAP Activate’s agile approach is built on the idea that requirements evolve. But they must be clear right from the start as the backlog entry, so that they can be reviewed, classified, and approved later. Clarity does not mean rigidity. It means writing requirements so they can be discussed, prioritized, tested, and traced - even as they may change later.

 A well formulated requirement contains four elements in one short sentence:

Who – the role that needs the functionality
When – the situation or trigger
What – the action or system behavior
Why – the intended business benefit

When these four parts are present, the requirement becomes verifiable. It can be confirmed during testing and explained during audit reviews. More importantly, it can be reused across teams and releases because it is self-contained and unambiguous.

The right format for SAP projects

SAP’s Agile method proposes the familiar User Story format: “As a [role], I want [feature], so that [business value].” In practice, this structure is often too generic for configuration and testing.

A better pattern for SAP requirements adds context and system behavior:

As [Role], when [Condition], the system will [Action] on [Object] so that [Benefit].

This sentence looks simple, but it solves three common problems:

1) It describes the trigger (when), which links to a real process step.
2) It defines the system reaction (will [Action]), which makes the behavior testable.
3) It keeps the business benefit explicit, which ties it back to value and approval.

This version includes all four elements: who, when, what, and why.
Anyone reading it should understands both the intent and the expected outcome.

Adding a “How to Demo” section

A practical way to make requirements even clearer is to include a short “How to Demo” note directly under the description. This is not a full test case but rather a quick outline of how someone would prove that the requirement works. This serves as a draft for formal test cases and ensures that requirements can be verified during Activate’s test preparation phase.

This small “How to demo” section acts as an early test-case draft. It helps reviewers visualize expected behavior and gives testers a ready starting point for building the formal Test Case later. In larger projects, these demo notes become a lightweight bridge between requirement authoring and structured testing, keeping intent, behavior, and verification tightly connected.

Finding the right level of detail

A well-written requirement should guide the Realize phase. Too much detail turns it into a mini-functional specification; too little makes it meaningless. The right level of abstraction sits between business intention and technical configuration.

When many team members are involved in requirements formulation, duplication can easily occur. Similar needs appear in different modules, often under different wording. To prevent this, each requirement should reference its related SAP Best Practice Process represented by an approved Scope Item. This simple linking helps identify overlaps early and supports reuse across workstreams.

From quick notes to refined requirements

In line with SAP Activate’s iterative principle, requirements may first be recorded in simple terms and refined later during backlog reviews and work package definition. What matters most in that moment is to capture the intent in a simplified form and then refine it later.

For example:
“Add a process step for automatic credit check approval before delivery creation.” → GAP

Such a note still has value. During later review, typically when preparing the related Work Package, the requirement can be reformulated to the full standard:

As a Sales Manager, when a sales order is saved and the customer exceeds the credit limit, the system will block delivery creation on the delivery document so that only approved orders can ship.

This two-step approach keeps workshops efficient while ensuring that every requirement ultimately meets the agreed structure before review, approval, and test preparation.

How to make this standard work in Jira?

Formulation discipline is easier to maintain when supported by a tool.
In Jira, you can create an automation rule that pre-populates the Description field of each new Requirement with a Activate-style structured template.

In the template, you can use a table to make the content easier to follow. Each author then only needs to fill in the blanks. This keeps every requirement standardized.

For simplicity, below the requirement you can add a simple list with the ‘How to demo’ steps.

Why it’s worth the effort?

A requirement is not a transcript of a workshop discussion. It is a helpful SAP governance standard that supports the SAP delivery lifecycle.

Teams that adopt this standardization rule quickly notice tangible benefits:
-> Requirements become easier to review and approve.
-> Test cases can be linked directly and generated faster.
-> Cross-team understanding improves, because every sentence follows the same logic.

Formulation discipline may feel like a big effort, but it pays back throughout the project lifecycle. Clear requirements accelerate testing, improve governance, and reduce rework.
